COVID-19 negative certification required.
The green countries are listed on Guidelines for border traffic during pandemic. All other countries.
Travellers from the countries that are non on the green list must provide one of the following documents:
• Proof of full vaccination. Validity: 7 days after the last vaccine dose.
• Proof of recovery from COVID-19 and receiving one dose of vaccine. It is equated to a complete covid-19 vaccination series.
• Proof of recovery from COVID-19. Validity: 6 months.
Children born in 2006 and earlier are not subjected to health security measures at the point of entry.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation.
There are no entry restrictions when arriving from EU and Schengen countries. However, all passengers (born in 2006 and earlier) arriving in Finland have to go through health security measures, which may include checking certificates or COVID-19 tests.
Note: All travellers arriving in Finland are still bound by the obligations stated in the Communicable Diseases Act which will remain in force until the end of June 2022.
column4:
THIS COUNTRY IS READY TO CONNECT TO THE EU DIGITAL COVID CERTIFICATE GATEWAY
Validity: 7 days after the last vaccine dose. Accepted vaccines: Comirnaty (Pfizer-BionTech), Spikevax (Moderna), Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca), Janssen (Johnson&Johnson), BIBP/Sinopharm, COVIDSHIELD, CoronaVac, COVAXIN.
column5:
Latest News: Authorities remove all COVID-19 travel restrictions for travelers from third countries (Schengen Visa Info 21.06.22).

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU: There are no entry restrictions when arriving from EU and Schengen countries.
Note: All travellers arriving in Finland are still bound by the obligations stated in the Communicable Diseases Act which will remain in force until the end of June 2022.
*Transit:

Transit on scheduled routes is permitted.

During the transit journey, traveller must remain in the transit area of the airport. In exceptional cases, transit travellers may also be permitted to enter the country. For example, a person may stay at a hotel near the airport if the waiting time for a connecting flight is too long. In this case, traveller entering the country will be bound by the obligations stated in the Communicable Diseases Act.

Destination countries may also require passengers to take a coronavirus test at transit airports. Waiting for the test and the test results is not in itself a ground for allowing entry during transit.



*From Third Countries:

Entry restrictions will end on 30 June 2022. Until then, the entry requirements depend on the guidelines for border traffic, according to Finland’s own national classification of risk areas.

 

Entry rules

 

Green list countries

 

There are no entry restrictions for residents of the countries and regions on the green list. However, all passengers (born in 2006 and earlier) arriving in Finland have to go through health security measures, which may include checking certificates or COVID-19 tests.

Note: All persons arriving in Finland are still bound by the obligations stated in the Communicable Diseases Act which will remain in force until the end of June 2022.

The green countries are listed on Guidelines for border traffic during pandemic.

 

All other countries

 

Travellers from the countries that are not on the green list must provide one of the following documents:

 

  • Proof of full vaccination.
    Validity: 7 days after the last vaccine dose.
    Accepted vaccines: Comirnaty (Pfizer-BionTech), Spikevax (Moderna), Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca), Jcovden (Janssen), BIBP/Sinopharm, COVIDSHIELD, CoronaVac, COVAXIN.
  • Proof of recovery from COVID-19 and receiving one dose of vaccine. It is equated to a complete COVID-19 vaccination series.
  • Proof of recovery from COVID-19. Validity: 6 months.

If a traveller has none of these documents, they should expect to be directed to a COVID-19 testing point at the entry.

 

Travellers can provide proof of vaccination or proof of recovery from COVID-19 with one of the following:

  • A valid ‘EU Digital COVID Certificate’ (EUDCC), meeting the criteria listed above
  • Certificates meeting the same requirements listed for the EUDCC (in English, Finnish or Swedish)

 

Children born in 2006 and earlier are not subjected to health security measures at the point of entry.

Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays



Internal Restrictions:
*Public spaces and services: The Finnish authorities have lifted the general recommendation on the use of face masks. Wearing a mask is still recommended in public indoor spaces and on public transport if you are seeking treatment or a test due to a suspected COVID-19 infection, have symptoms of a respiratory infection, or if you know you have been exposed to coronavirus.
